newsitem.title: UK: Hambros sees gradual banking revenue lift.
newsitem.headline: Hambros sees gradual banking revenue lift.

text.p: British investment banking group Hambros Plc said on Wednesday that the profitability of its banking business would grow through a gradual increase in revenues and continuing strong demand for independent advice.

Hambros, which announced pretax profits of 35.0 million pounds ($57.85 million) for the first half compared with a 7.7 million pound loss for the same period in 1995, said second half profits from its investment group would not match the first, but it expected "considerable improvement" in its subsidiaries.
Hambros sees gradual banking revenue lift
Lord Hambro, the group's chairman, said he would retire from his post in July 1997 and be succeeded by Sir Chips Keswick, currently group chief executive.

Bad debt provisions for the period were 5.9 million pounds compared with 23.5 million in the same period in 1995. Hambro said the full effect of a drive to reduce the banking group's cost base "should steadily become evident during the course of the next two years" and the benefits were already showing.

Hambro said the banking group had recruited well-qualified individuals to fill key posts and is "actively pursuing a number of initiatives which would strengthen our core businesses both in the UK and abroad".

Hambro said the Hambro Countrywide estate agency subsidiary and the Hambro Insurance Services arm should both produce considerable improvements in their contributions, in particular Hambro Countrywide. Despite a challenging environment for the group as a whole, prospects were good, he added. ($1=.6050 Pound)
